Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Bilingual Literacy Assessment and Skill Tracker
Award.AbstractNarration:
his SBIR Phase I project will develop an innovative application, geared towards the growing emergent bilingual population which enters the educational system. Despite their growing size (approximately 20 percent of the total US population), emergent bilinguals still do not have adequate support to succeed in an academic setting, and are often victims of a subtractive bilingualism process, which eventually favors the acquisition of English at the expense of the home language. When this happens, the individual child loses a valuable economic and cultural resource, as well as the cognitive benefits associated with bilingualism. In turn, society loses its multilingual resources and a wealth of cultural knowledge, which is necessary for trade and diplomacy with foreign nations, among other things. Therefore, the goal of the project is to track the progress of bilingual students throughout their education. It aims to support the students' bilingual development by providing a research-based, standard-aligned, and child-friendly bilingual literacy and cognitive skills assessment tool accompanied by an educational platform where teachers, parents, and students can collectively collaborate to promote bilingualism.


The project consists of a mobile-device and/or web-based automated bilingual assessment of reading, writing and oral skills, that provides real-time results to teachers (and parents) of emergent bilinguals. The assessment is intuitive, adapting to each child, and is complemented by recommended activities that are automatically tailored to each student's needs. The goal is to help teachers gain an in-depth understanding of the bilingual student's strengths and weaknesses, and to rule out cognitive deficits that are usually wrongly ascribed to bilinguals. It is also to help teachers and parents gauge, develop, and nurture the specific skill set that emergent bilinguals bring with them and that strongly benefit many aspects of society. The R&D plan aims at developing an innovative product that stands out from other existing solutions. The key differentiating features are: its focus on bilingual children and its adaptability in accepting bilingual answers for the assessments, its capacity of assessing oral skills in children thanks to the integration of a speech recognizer that will be refined by integrating machine learning algorithms trained on children speech data, and the option for each student to receive a personalized bundle of analytics and activities that fit his/her profile.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project addresses the educational needs of the growing school-age emergent bilingual population, as well as the loss of cultural diversity and linguistic acumen for society as a whole. According to the latest Census data, 23 percent of school-age children speak a language other than English at home. Of those children, at least five million were classified as English Language Learners in 2016 according to the National Center for Education Statistics. However, this particular portion of the U.S. population does not have adequate support to succeed in an academic setting, often becoming victims of a subtractive bilingualism process that eventually favors the acquisition of English at the expense of the home language. When this happens, the individual child loses a valuable economic and cultural resource, as well as the cognitive benefits associated with bilingualism. In turn, society as a whole loses its multilingual resources and a wealth of cultural knowledge, which is necessary for trade and diplomacy with foreign nations, among other things. 

Our project?s goal is to provide equal access to education for every child in America, regardless of their dominant language and socio-economic status, while preserving a strong societal and economic asset for the U.S.: a plethora of languages mastered by skilled and educated students. To this end, we are giving teachers and principals a tool that will afford them detailed data about their students and in-depth understanding of their characteristics and needs, while allowing them to improve their school?s educational and budgetary performance in these uncertain times. 

As a first step to achieve this goal, the main objective of our Phase I project was to design, develop, and pilot a fully-automated and child-friendly language and literacy assessment app for emergent Kindergarten bilinguals to measure pre-reading, pre-writing, listening, speaking and cognitive skills in both English and Spanish.

Our Phase I project had the following main achievements and key outcomes:

  1. The app turned out to be child-friendly as kids did not seem to have any problems navigating it. They also enjoyed the stories and asked their parents for more apps of this sort, which has led us to believe that developing literacy improvement activities in Phase II of this project is the obvious next step for our project. 

  2. When we tested the speech recognizer integrated in the app, it worked better than expected with children for both Spanish and English. We have shown that a speech recognizer can be used with relative success to assess oral skills in young children and to accurately determine their dominant language. 

  3. We designed a set of questions that would help us determine the assessment-takers? dominant language in order to personalize the assessment to their needs, and we wrote a simple algorithm to achieve this goal. The warm-up questions predicted the dominant language correctly with an accuracy of 50 percent and higher when we compared results to the dominant language that parents had reported as dominant for their children. Not only that but children scored better in most of the skills in the language that the assessment had predicted as their dominant language.

  4. We were able to successfully collect and store children's speech samples. This children?s speech database is key to the development of our own speech recognizer in Phase II of this project.

  5. We were successful in achieving full automatization of the assessment process, including the assessment of oral skills, and in providing real time results.
